segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hey, so this is the last talk, so I won't be very long, I'm going to try to keep you
before parting, so let's start.
So who I am, I'm the guy who's working for CertPL, doing mostly malware research, as
a hobby I work, and work.
I play in CTFs with Dragon Sector and doing exploitation there.
My main interest is automatization of things and formal methods, so symbolic execution
is something I like and do a lot, and Angry is actually quite a shitty tool.
So that's my Twitter, and I was playing for Locked Shields as a Polish blue team member
for the last two years.
I'm not playing this year because I'm here and the execution is going right now, it's
the second day, so they probably buried it in much of the work, so there was an idea
I would be streaming them live, but they didn't agree for it, I don't know why.
So quick agenda, I'll talk a little bit about what the Locked Shields are, and some things
about the blue team, red team, other teams that are playing in and have participation
there, and some stories we've managed to encounter during those two years.
So I was approached by my boss some time ago and asked, there is a cyber maneuvers,
do you want to participate in there, and I was like, what?
So that was something I was imagining that it would look like that, they give us keyboards
and throw them at our enemies or what's not, but after some explanation it turns out they're
attacking a bunch of computers, a lot of soldiers attacking themselves, and that would be fun
if it would look that way, unfortunately it looks like that, so we have a lot of work
to do, and not many people.
So in more concrete terms, Locked Shields are the cyber maneuvers created by NATO, it
runs for I think five or six years now, it's not only NATO members, there are a couple
of others, but mostly Europeans, the point of it is to exercise how the defending actually
works in combat, attacks as well, because most of the power and most of the things are
put on the side of the blue teams, and there's a lot of work there, but part of, you have
to give a couple of people to blue teams, but you can assign as well a couple of people
to red teams, so they can exercise offensive security as well.
Some numbers, you can read it like this, blah, blah, blah, it's on their side.
So a couple of numbers, if I don't remember, they're from last year, 600 members that was
participating, 2,000 systems, 20 teams, blue team member, you can read it, I don't have
to read it for you.
I think you can read it?
All right, cool.
So as you can see, it's quite a lot, it's not a small one, and that's how it looks.
This is a visualization of the network, and that's something, because they try to create
very realistic networks with a lot of different things.
So the first layer is obviously the layer network, you have to connect between different
countries and talk to them, attack them, defend from them, attack from red teams, and that's
how the one blue team infrastructure looked like last year.
Except for the red parts, the red parts were only for red team, so for example, we don't
know that there was a rogue IP, why not?
At some point it starts popping up and popping servers.
So that's like, I don't know, 20, 40 machines with different kinds of Linuxes, Windowses,
there's a BSD somewhere here, there's a BSD, there's a SCADA, there's a drone, whatever,
rotors, firewalls, whatever.
So it's a huge, huge infrastructure, a lot of work.
This year they removed the limitation for people, and last year and the year before
the limitation was 12 people for all this network, and not only for this network, because
since this is a military, so they are structured, right, so they have to have someone that's
running it, so there is a CEO, and there is a second CEO, because you need to have an
auditant, probably, and there are a lot of things that we're talking about, like there
is problems with law and journalism and stuff like that, forensic.
So basically you've got eight working technical people to defend this shitload of the systems.
That's why the slide with the one guy with seven hands.
And there is another addition, since this is a live system, they have a Blondies, and
the Blondie is your normal user, right?
It gets emails, clicks on everything, infects your machines, and complains, like, my system
doesn't work, I cannot look at my, I will say something quite offensive so I don't stop
myself, I cannot look at, hmm, what's not, YouTube isn't working, you're blocking my
access, passwords need to be changed, stuff like that.
But mostly you run malware on your every system.
Some scoring, because, you know, they have to be the best one and the worst one.
Most important part was the availability of the services, actually.
So you have availability and something else, and usability, so they distinguish between
availability so the server is actually living and running, and usability if it's responding
correctly to the actual tests.
And, you know, since this was, you have to defend, so the attacks were also important.
And there were some injects, like, additional life moments, like, you know, someone kill
your servers or what's not, or, you know, the journalist found out that you are hacking
back or stuff like that.
Normal life bullshit.
Some penalties for, you know, since you want to defend yourself, you want to stay always
online.
So the penalties if you have to restart VMs or what's not, stuff like that.
Normal things you can think about.
So a little bit about WOTIM.
That's how we actually were split up.
I don't know if every team was something like that, but basically you split yourselves based
on things you have to defend, right?
So there was some custom and not only custom, so normal web applications, some Windows stations,
workstations to defend, Linux workstations, there was a drone and some SCADAS, network
attacks, like, you know, PGP hijacks, stuff like that.
Some media, some people that were responsible to contact with media, because you have to
inform someone that your site was defaced, organization, like I said, the CEO and things.
Before you inform media about things, you have to consult your log guy about it, and
there was a forensic assignment as well, it was quite simple, you have to, like, two VMs
or stuff, you have to acquire memory from it and, you know, perform investigation how
the site was hacked and used to attack someone else.
Different problems for different years, but basically the same forensic shit.
Some tools that we are trying to use.
One thing that you can not only have access to those machines, you can come with your
own two machines, that's much, apparently, for them.
One is for forensics, so it's useless, and the second one you can use your tools, you
put some tools on it, because you can not run, you know, everything on the workstations.
But the size of the machine is not very big, it's like 42 gigas, so that's kind of okay.
So, you know, basic things, IDS, EPS, SAP, SIPs.
We tried to use Splunk last year, and it wasn't working at all.
This year they bought a license, and they fill up the license in two hours, during test
run, not the actual exercises.
Oh, that's something I forgot to mention.
So the exercise is split in two parts, let's say.
They give a notice about it in March or something, I'm not sure, mostly getting information about
it in the beginning of March.
So they have a preparation time, you know, assemble the team, assemble Avengers, whatever.
Then you have a testing period, right, you have written your tools, you have your preparation
going on, team split by assignments, and then you have access for two days, three days actually,
three days to your environment, you know, to test your stuff, to get yourself familiar
with the environment, and after that they wipe it off and start again.
So you have one day more before execution, and there is a two-day of execution itself.
Since this is military, they start at 7 a.m.
That's fantastic for me.
Okay, so back to tools.
There is a lot of pressure put on collaboration between teams, and one of the sponsors or
organizers at Lazion, I think, so they use their call-up system, Jabber, to collaborate
and exchange information between teams and between other organizers, so that's something
we have to use it a lot to communicate, excuse me.
Something to, you know, exchange notes, like we use Etherpad for it for a couple of years,
it works quite well, and since this is your strange infrastructure, you don't know really
how to operate on this, there are a shitload of the code that you wrote for yourself, like
scripts to monitor and maintain, administrate, what's not.
I think there were like 5,000, 6,000 lines of Python and shell combined.
And for forensic, you know, the normal tools like REMNUX or whatever, I don't know forensic
at all.
So some information about red teaming.
I don't know much because I wasn't part of a red team, and I talked only to a couple
of those a couple of years ago, I don't remember anything.
But basically they are split in four groups, the networking attacks, client-side attacks,
and web attacks, and obviously organization stuff.
And tools, the main tool for client-side and the client-side part of the red team is most
visible and mostly described in after-action reports that they're releasing afterwards.
So they used Cobblestrike, probably because Rafał Miuczy is a sponsor and partner of
this exercise.
So if they use Cobblestrike, they use custom Cobblestrike scripts.
I know a shitload of post-PowerShells were used and dropped, and it was probably a big
problem at the beginning for our defenders because they were not familiar with scripts.
For obfuscation, Shelter, Valley, some custom crypto were made, and some collaboration tools
as well.
So there are four phases that are visible for players.
The phase one, the attackers try to first recon a little bit the infrastructure, your
tools, and get initial access.
Then they try to maintain the access and elevate their privileges, steal some confidential
data and go on.
And the fourth phase is when there is no barriers, nothing at all, there is real havoc and no
shit runs from the skies.
So to be successful, there are other teams that are not composed from the countries that
are participating, but from the organizers as a yellow, green, and white team.
One is responsible for injects, one is responsible for network.
And then, you know, the organizers themselves.
So I will ask if you have any questions about it so far.
If I didn't miss anything, you need to need something more before I go to do some stories.
Okay, seems okay.
And so let's go.
So first story is the bootstrap.
So I was told, I was invited to this and was told by our keynote speaker that there are
backdoors everywhere and, you know, we have to fear because everything you do will be
backdoored and you cannot trust your tools and your environment at all.
So I said, fuck it.
I wrote something that actually they're removing everything from it.
So if every server is backdoored and I cannot trust my tools, so I need to run my own, wrote
my own, or use my own.
So the best way, since most of the tools were either Debian or Ubuntu, so that makes it
easy.
I was responsible for Linux, obviously.
I have no idea about Windows, so I only can reverse my work on those.
So the best idea was to bootstrap them from the scratch.
Probably you cannot use it normally because, you know, there is a chance that DPKG and
Vuget and what's not are backdoored and are running something else.
So let's just use BusyBox, precompiled, statically linked, totally safe.
So that's something like this.
But since we're bootstrapping and doing something else, there is never enough backdoors, right?
Probably it was spoiled at the beginning.
I wasn't there at the morning.
So what we did, we actually put another backdoor in those backdoors so we can maintain access.
To make it easy and not possible to access, for Red Team to give them another access,
we used custom SSL, BackConnect, not BackConnect, but BindShell.
I was thinking about writing it in C, but I said, eh, fuck it, Python is faster.
So faster was done.
Python is good for this.
You can create quite nice, hide it quite nice if you just pipe it through Python interpreter,
not leaving any files on disk.
One other thing I was working on is a drone.
It's always fun to hug the drone, right?
That was the only part that was actually close to Red Teaming or, you know, something Red
on part of the Blue Teams.
You have a drone that you're trying to control, but you don't have access to it.
You can only send comments to it.
But so you have to, there was some custom C++ application that was quite easy to analyze
and, you know, and pwn.
So I wrote a couple of bugs there, and you have to take over it, then you can fix it
and try to, you know, get rid of the Red Team from there.
It was actually kind of fun because we were chasing each other.
They were trying to remove my shells.
I was removing their shells, you know, and going for and forth.
It was kind of fun.
This year they're actually trying to remove the drone as a custom C++ application.
They give them a real drone to some extent.
Not the real drone probably as a hardware, but the protocol they are using is actually
a real protocol that is used in drones right now.
And they don't have to hack it.
They have to, you know, only defend it.
That's as far as I know.
Other thing was SCADA.
I know shit about SCADA.
Our colleagues know shit about SCADA.
So well, that was a problem.
It actually was real Siemens PLCs going to be defended.
There was a Windows machine.
Let's go a couple of slides before.
There is a SCADA thing.
It was only access.
So the road to here was kind of complex for a Red Team because they have to go through
firewalls and only one machine to being popped.
So since they are involving the first time, it wasn't very complex.
There was a real PLCs, but they were not used.
It was only a red button that you have to protect.
It was a custom .NET application and you cannot do anything about it.
You know, keep pushing the button.
So if they managed to push a red button, you have to push a green button to reset the plant.
The PLCs were protecting or running, I don't know, running a power plant that was powering
your servers.
So if the power plant went down, your servers went down and you basically lose.
Last year, they removed the .NET application and used actual real stuff for Siemens.
You have to program it and things like that.
I don't know much about it because I'm not a specialist on it.
Funny thing, two years ago when they were attacking it, it was a custom .NET application.
It renders at the phase four of a couple of teams.
They actually just removed the DLLs and made trash of it so it was crashing, the application
wasn't working.
That was a huge problem for the teams because no one had the backups.
Another funny thing, so, well, let's go back in once, we have a lot of time.
This is one crucial thing, right?
The phase four is always the funniest one because there are no boundaries, you can do
everything and they can do everything for you.
So they attacked the firewall.
The firewall was obviously bugged.
When you do a trace on OS, it tries to connect to something, that's not normal behavior for
OS.
Apparently, you have to have kitties somewhere, so I put some kitties.
So it was the game back and forward, right?
We were trying to find, there was not only one bug, there was a bug in SSH and stuff
like that, normal things, keys.
So they were trying to reboot our firewall, block the, remove every IP table we had there
and block us away.
We tried to remove them.
The biggest problem is we cannot do anything to them, that's kind of lame, but apparently
it's illegal to hack everyone else.
Which is not true because I hacked some drones and tried to restore them.
So that was the only fun part about hacking things.
Since the problem was with drones and most of the blue teams were composed from defenders,
not attackers, so they have little to no idea about exploitation, so they cannot,
they don't know how to take over the drones.
So helping was kind of rewarded because extra cooperation and stuff like that, that's something
you can brag about in papers, so media have run on it.
So the good thing was you can hack other drones and give them access, or not, or crash them
or stuff like that.
So the battle of firewall.
The battle of firewall, we managed to keep our sessions with a couple of reboots, mostly
because of the Python bug there, and apparently some funny thing is, I don't know why, but
when we opened, so when we had Windows, normal Linux sessions, when they removed the firewall
rules and blocked them, everything was down, our sessions were down, but one other guy
had a Windows and a couple of PuTTY sessions opened and they would stay alive.
I don't know why, but apparently, so our defense was open like 20 or 40 PuTTY sessions on his
computer and waiting, what happens, one hour dies, we go to the guy, move the fuck out
and take over his computer to manage to recover, and we managed to stay on top.
At the last, I think, two minutes of the exercise, someone just turned down our VM server for
it, probably from VMware, but I don't know how.
Some lessons.
First thing to do, every time on Linux, remove access password, apparently not every team
was doing this, and they were popped by just default passwords, remove them, use SSH keys,
that's the best, and the basic getaway from this exercise for most of the defenders, obviously,
when you lose access, you need to regain access, and you have some bugs, it's easy, but do
it smart, right?
Don't do it custom, don't do it hardcore password, use some serious cryptography, like, you know,
SSL, SSL certs.
Don't trust your AVs.
That's actually, I will expand on this a little bit later, in a few minutes.
And one thing about being a blue team member, there is never, that's the idea, there is
never too much logging, as much information as you can get, except if you have to look
on the manually, because, you know, the CMs are not, you probably have to use a normal
license for ArcSight, so they are kind of expensive to buy, so they were not that easy
to, you have only one machine, so you have to, you know, choose carefully what you're
actually trying to use, but, yeah, logging, too much logging, if you have used your own
eyes already, it's actually not that good.
When you write custom scripts, try to think about that something will be fucked up, and
you cannot control every environment, that's actually, who does know how their Linux AV
actually works, right?
So the thing was, my tools were, at some point, were trying to, were updating the system,
and the AV that was put on, it was a risk condition, basically, with other guys, but
they put AVs on, and I was trying to restore the systems, and the AV was not very likely
to run under new libsys, and since they were already preloaded, they run, fucked up all
the system, it was totally unusable for a whole part of the execution.
That was secondary DNS, so that was kind of a problem for us, but we managed to reroute
it to another machine and use secondary DNS from somewhere else, so no one actually noticed
that we didn't, our one machine is totally down for every time.
And that will be me.
Do we have any questions?
I cannot give you mine.
We did not use any CMS, well we used, as I said, kind of manual logging, we started
out with logging of syscalls and executed things, and tried to, you know, the custom
rules that were pinging us on if something strange happened, like, you know, the binary
that shouldn't do, connects to some network that is probably controlled by Red Team, so
that was a, let's say, custom, very basic CM.
This year I think they are trying to do some CMS, but I have no idea how they will be doing
this and how they will work.
So the question was if we thought about Elasticsearch, yes, but as I said, we have one machine with
42 gigabytes of RAM, and it won't work.
We need to put the Suricata there and stuff, that actually can help us more than CM.
We don't really need to go, you know, every time back to see how the compromise was made,
we need to only see the compromise that was made, so the storage is actually not that
important.
So I guess, I'm assuming that the purpose of the exercise is to give the Blue Team experience
and something that they can translate into the real world, but some of the techniques
that you're talking about can be kind of questionable in the real world, so I'm kind of wondering
if you can talk a little bit about that.
Most of the questionable tactics are probably mine, not the actual guys, and I don't have
like high limits on what I can do, I like doing stuff that are kind of on the limits,
but as I said, there is a legal team, right?
So they were, so their purpose is to justify our steps, to make it, and they are working
on the real legal framework, not the mixed one.
So I guess, so that's something, and I'm quite sure it's serving their purpose because, you
know, the guys are having more and more experience in this, and the collaboration parties, that's
when they are actually putting a lot of effort on it.
You know, one of the things I actually missed and forgot to say, one of the parts, and there
is a lot of points on this, is to report the actual incidents and, you know, try to help
other people, you know, publish information on IOCs and stuff like that, so that's something.
I was going to ask the same question, you kind of told me a story about, you know, red
team hacking the blue team, blue team kind of counter-hacking almost red team, or assuming
breaches, so what was the big lessons learned?
Because this is probably like a huge NATO exercise, I assume the energy behind it, or
the time spent on that must be huge, and we've seen like, you know, assume everything is
breached, or everything, what's, if you abstract from the hacking stuff, what are the lessons
learned from, you know, the European NATO or something?
Is it that the blue teams need more CMs, or is it that blue teams need more cooperation?
What is the real result beyond, you know, assume breaches everywhere?
So the question was, I'll short it, okay, so the question was, what's the real result
from this for NATO members, I guess, right?
I don't know.
Well, I do it for, I was doing this for fun, because it was hard, but it's fun.
From them, I guess, that's for sure the knowledge of techniques that are used in real world,
what they can, what they have to predict that probably can happen.
Collaboration is something that's very important, exchanging information.
And for some part of it, you know, the learning, the part of team that's actually in red team,
right, they're learning how to hack.
So that's something that's probably important in military as well.
One again?
Like getting some associations and decorating stuff, is what would happen in the real world?
So the question is, how realistic those attacks are?
So I think very, right?
The problem is, what's the objective, right?
So first they have to defend themselves to get any access.
That's something, that's normal pen testing that we're doing, like normal industry work.
I actually focused most on the first place, because it's most fun.
Maybe that was a problem, and I shouldn't do it.
I should focus on other things.
But their objective then is, you know, to wreak havoc, destroy everything, no limits.
So that's, if the real hackers will be doing this, I think so.
But the objective will be to, you know, destroy, blow off the bridges or what's not,
destroy the infrastructure to some point.
So I think so.
But I'm not the military guy, I have no idea about it.
I'm doing this for fun, so I cannot tell what's the NATO idea about it.
They're doing this, and they get positive feedback from it.
So one thing that's very valuable, I think, and they're expanding it a lot,
is the after action reports.
So the description of how the exercise actually were run from their point,
from the point of organizers and from the point of the Red Team.
And one thing that's actually very important, after the execution,
there is a day or two days' workshop that works on the recorded traffic from the exercise
to show what was happening, how to analyze the traffic, get information from there.
So that's something that's very important as well.
Something more, or are we done?
I think we're done, so thank you.
